samples.situation: found out my fiance was cheating on me

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: I am feeling really down today.  My fiance was cheating on me and everything has pretty much crumbled all around me.

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: Oh my I'm so sorry that happened to you. I can't completely relate, but my parents are going through something very similar after 25 years of marriage. Tell me more about it.

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: I'm glad you haven't and so sorry to hear about them. We have been together for 13 years and have an 11 year old.  He has been dating someone for nearly two years and i had no clue.  I am so embarrassed and feel so stupid.

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: I am so sorry. Does your child know? I have a 10 year old and she is struggling with my parents, we lived with them for the first 2 years of her life and have always been 15 minutes away since. I completely understand why you feel the way you do that is to be expected. You are not stupid and I'm sure its not you. Have you spoken to your fiance about this since you found out?

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: He is somewhat aware that something is going on but not quite sure what.  One of us will be moving out so it will need to be explained to him soon.  We have talked and he just denies everything.  He told me I'm crazy and they are just "friends

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: I would love to believe that but unfortunately I know that isn't true.  I'm just overwhelmed with so may questions that he is not answering.

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: I'm so sorry. From personal experience, my best advice is to be as direct as possible. Demand respect and answers that you deserve after 13 years.

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: If he will not answer your questions, thats all the answers you need. How did you find out?

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: I can't even imagine how you feel. Clarity and answers are so important right now for you... no matter if it is true or not. That is a long time to be with someone.

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: That is great advice! It's very hard to stand up for yourself sometimes especially when you are emotionally devastated. I visited him unannounced at work one day and they were having lunch together.  I had no idea who she was and she got up and ran off.  Upon further investigation, I checked phone records, receipts, any other thing I could find and all the evidence was there. two hour conversations, gifts from women's stores that weren't given to me.

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: Oh my gosh. There's all the answers you need right there. I'm so sorry. He wont even speak to you about it? No excuses anything? Have you told family?

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: I haven't told anyone yet.  He just denies everything or has the perfect excuse for whatever I bring up.  I have confronted her as well via text. She states she doesn't even know who he is.  Really? So yeah.  I just want to grieve it and be over with it. I think just talking about it had helped a lot.

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: You must express this in some way to let this out. It's not healthy to let your anger bottle up. I'm sure you're angry, rightfully so... do you have any hobbies to occupy your mind until you get things sorted?

generated_dialog.speaker: seeker
generated_dialog.content: Also, I've started to think about what my next steps should be. I don't want to rush into decisions, but it's hard to just sit with everything.

generated_dialog.speaker: supporter
generated_dialog.content: It's completely understandable to feel that way. It sounds like you're trying to find a balance between processing your emotions and planning for the future.

generated_dialog.speaker: seeker
generated_dialog.content: Exactly. I know I can't just ignore this, but it's overwhelming. I want to be strong for my child too.

generated_dialog.speaker: supporter
generated_dialog.content: Finding that strength is important, especially for your child's sake. Have you considered talking to a counselor or someone who could help guide you through this?

samples.situation: I have been self-isolating since March which has made my chronic depression worse than ever. I live alone and have not touched another human being in all that time.

Nothing like feeling the person who is paid to help you refusing to talk to you

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content:
That seems like a frustrating experience. What were your expectations of the session you were supposed to have? Did you feel like what you learned in your previous session would have helped you with dealing with what you typically work on in your mental health sessions
?

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: I feel like he didn't help at all. Up to that point we mostly just talked about politics or whatever. I'm a charity patient, he get's paid through the organization, but because of my financial difficulties, I'm not paying. I think he saw that as a shortcoming on my part.

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: I think that is definitely one way to look at it. But another way to look at your situation is you figured out a therapist who isn't worth seeing. That brings you one step closer to finding one who does actually help you. All you need to do now, is do some research and find someone who has your best interest in mind. Believe me, there are great therapists and terrible therapists. You just need to find one of the good ones now.

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: I'm not sure I can find another who I don't have to pay. My insurance has a $20 copay and if I had to pay that I wouldn't be able to buy groceries. prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: If you have financial issues and you need the help from a therapist you deserve the treatment. One thing you can do is apply for Medicaid and EBT. The state you live in will give you money to pay for groceries and to get help from a therapist for free if you don't have a high enough income. It may be worth looking into because all you really need to do is fill out some forms and likely you will be approved. When I was younger and struggling, this had happened to me and I received both of these benefits and it totally turned my life around. I think it can do the same for you as well.

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: I'm on Medicare and supplemental insurance. I didn't know you can, possibly, see one for free. I'll look into that. That is helpful.

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: Sure thing. What are some of the coping strategies you've been practicing with your prior therapist?

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: I asked him to help me with some but all he would say is that I should stop vaping (I switched from smoking some years ago). I told him it feels like I'm walking a tightrope and he's suggesting I get rid of the safety net without giving me something else, some other way to cope. He said that's not what a therapist is supposed to do and that my resistance shows I don't really want to change.

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: I can see how that comment he made would be frustrating. If you feel like vaping, you should continue to do; however, what happens if say you go somewhere and find yourself in a stressful position? What would be strategy you could use in order to recenter yourself? Strategies are important as they balance us when we experience stressors that through us off. Have you ever thought about meditation?

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: I asked him about meditation and if he could recommend something. He wouldn't. I have only been able to do it successfully once, at the meditation gardens when I visited my son in San Diego some years back. Since I can't always get to that kind of natural setting, I was hoping he could give me some resources. Do you know of any place I can find some?

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: Oh yes. Me personally, I like to scour youtube and find an environment with a sound I enjoy such as the beach. When I listen to that sound, I try to put myself by closing my eyes while sitting on the floor and breathing deeply for some time. It may be worth a try for you. I hope it helps you. Good luck!

generated_dialog.speaker: seeker
generated_dialog.content: Also, sometimes I feel like I'm just a burden to my therapist. It seems like no one really wants to help me, and it's making everything worse.

generated_dialog.speaker: supporter
generated_dialog.content: That sounds really painful to feel that way. It's hard to feel like you're not getting the support you need.

generated_dialog.content: I really think that if I can’t find help, then I’m destined to fail and never get better. It feels like I’ll always be stuck in this darkness.

generated_dialog.content: Yes, it must be incredibly difficult to feel like you're destined to fail. Given everything you've been through, it makes sense that it feels that way.

samples.situation: I'm feeling very lonely lately and I don't have many friends to turn to.  This makes me sad because I've always had only a few friends but now they have families and kids and I feel more alone than ever.

Getting a puppy       In the mean time,  I think it helps to try to keep busy.   Is there goals you can set for yourself each day?  Like maybe working on a room for a puppy, to take a walk outside each day, an area of the house that should get cleaned, or start a new hobby (like finding a book you have been meaning to read)

prefix_dialog.content: You're definitely right I have a lot to be excited about.  I like the idea of setting goals each day. samples.situation: I am upset with my best friend over the results of the election. We generally agree not to discuss politics, but the controversy over Biden's win over Trump has us split. I am angry that she keeps bringing it up.

prefix_dialog.content: well look, One thing I have always learnt about people who push others to the core is that they always have that competitive spirit in them to always want to win while hurting others feelings

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: what do you think of that

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: She typically is not like this... but I can kind of see that point. Especially considering how upset she was 4 years ago when Trump won

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: I get it now. I believe she feels like she has finally gotten what she was yearning for after four years of Trumps administration and now she is elated that her candidate has finally won right?

prefix_dialog.content: That's probably true

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: I guess I should just let her have her day?

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: Pretty much... over 25 years actually

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: wow that's a long time. How about you letting her know how you really feel about what she is doing to you emotionally. What do you think the outcome might be?

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: I'm not sure... our political difference is a recent thing. However, I will try that and see what happens. We've been through a lot together over the years so it's probably not going to end our friendship. Thanks for your advice. I do feel better about things.

Sometimes when one let's their friends know what is really bothering them makes the friends trust them more given that they are open with them and could tell them what they feel deep inside. That's what true friendship is about. It works wonders

prefix_dialog.content: That's true. Again thank you and I hope the rest of your day goes well. Goodbye.

prefix_dialog.content: You are welcome. Bye

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: I have talked to him repeatedly.  Each time, he assures me that he understands my concerns and that he's going to get things together.  Literally, within a day or two, I hear from a mutual friend or family member that he's reverted back to doing things that are sociopathic.

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: ok. dealing with someone with bi-polar disorder can be really tough and challenging but it is not there fault that they are acting the way they are. They just honestly can not help it. I know you are doing everything you can to help him and to stop him from acting that way.

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: You're right.  Mental illness, in all of its forms, is especially challenging.  Physical illness is more easy to understand, of course.

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: Funny you ask.  He's a grown man - 35-years old.  I've never known him to have this issue, which seems so strange to me.

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: I understand a lot.

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: Thanks for being so engaged and sympathetic.  It does make me feel better just to unload anonymously on here.  Thanks for carrying my burden and offering your support.

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: i got you. having a mental illness is challenging and i can provide you some suggestions.

samples.situation: I just feel generally down.

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: I also already have to schedule and routinize my day because I work and go to school from home, so I make sure to give myself breaks where I literally must get up and leave my desk, be in another room for a little while.

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: Yes, i like to be up to enjoy the mornings but i am also hard to get woken up

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: Bad cycle

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: Now that is intractable

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: Sometimes, to me, the enormity of the universe is calming to my anxiety.  Being assured that I mean absolutely nothing is nice sometimes.

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: Not in a scary, better-off-dead kind of way, but in the way that a galaxy is a slow moving explosion.  I'm a flea to the universe.

generated_dialog.speaker: seeker

generated_dialog.content: That sounds really challenging. It's tough when you're trying to balance everything while feeling overwhelmed.

generated_dialog.speaker: seeker
generated_dialog.content: What should I do? I have to decide whether to push myself to complete the project by tomorrow or take some time off to deal with my feelings. Which option is better for me?

generated_dialog.speaker: supporter
generated_dialog.content: I can understand how overwhelming this must feel for you. It's really hard to manage everything in times like this.

samples.violation_reason: Turn 4 is a clear V3 violation because it only provides general empathy and validation without addressing the Seeker's explicit request for practical guidance on what to do regarding their situation, despite the urgency and choice presented in Turn 3.

samples.situation: I dont know what to do with out her.

I think I got anxious last week when I had a tire go flat and took my car in to get it fixed.  I found out I need all new tires and new brakes.  Not easy on a fixed income.  Plus I am widowed.
